I really like Gojek, and I really like the people I work with and the projects I've worked on, so it breaks my heart to write this.

 I want to give a clear understanding of what to expect when someone joins 

I'm writing this review 2 days after Gojek executed layoffs of ~10% of the staff or around 1300 people. 

A lot of designers were also badly affected. There were multiple leaks to the media beforehand that the management either denied or refused to comment on, and then all of a sudden without warning conducted it.

They conducted the layoffs very badly, announcing it in the morning, and then we had to wait the entire day to know if our role was safe or not. It was a very cruel and anxiety inducing way to do the layoff, and those who remain are stressed and demoralised. 

The reason they did this layoff was because they had made really bad financial decisions and were running at heavy losses, and were under pressure to reach profitability. 

And this is the big con of Gojek - the company is very quick to layoff people. It's happened 3 times (2019, 2020 and 2022) and each time it's been badly handled. The way they have botched this layoff, and the less-than-generous severance and benefits should be a pause for anyone who wants to join in the future. 

More than that, there are some big organisational issues with how the recruitment and HR functions work. The comp bands are very wide, and there is an opaque negotiation process where the negotiator aggressively tries to benchmark your compensation to what you were earning in your previous job. 

People end up leaving money on the table, and those who are more aggressive or able to game the system are the ones who win out. Further the performance review and bell curving unfairly penalises new joiners.

 At the time of year end performance review, I like to think I performed very well, as per my stakeholder reviews, and the designs that I shipped, but I was rated a 3 out of 5 (Meets Expectations). My manager said they couldn’t do anything because I had been at Gojek for less than a year and the maximum rating I am allowed is 3. This seems to be an unwritten rule, and in my opinion it is very stupid. 

If the maximum is a 3, then why allow PMR for people before one year at all? this kind of bell curving and being force fitted a grade, despite manager’s own recommendation just leaves a bad taste in my mouth. I wouldn’t complain so much, but my bonus was dependent on my performance review, and I lose money because of this policy. 

Then I finished a year around the time of the mid-year review. My manager then told me that a HR rule was that I had to finish a year’s worth of appraisal cycles. This meant to be considered for a promotion, I had to wait 18 months for the second end of year cycle to be considered for a promotion, when I had joined underleveled anyway. 

Gojek also claims to have a Learning and Development budget but in practice it's implemented very badly - 3 of us from our team applied for a grant to attend a conference. Part of the process means you pay in advance and get reimbursed. I alone from my team mates did not get reimbursed due to some technical issue by the HR. So I was out a substantial amount of money for the conference. My manager felt bad about it, and tried to pay me from his own pocket - which is insane. 

As an employee, giving referrals is a painful enough process that I've stopped doing it. Recruiters ignore referrals for weeks, or ghost the candidates I refer, leading to them being upset at me, and negatively affecting my reputation. 

Finally the org has a shiny object syndrome, leading to reorganisations every six months, and a lot of confusion internally as to what initiatives to be focused on. In my time here, I have experienced 3 reorgs.
pros: For a product designer, Gojek is a great place to be. They have a high bar for hiring, and are heavily invested in tooling, processes and best practices, and train the designers in that. I have seen the evolution in how I think, and how I execute projects over the span since I have joined here. Gojek, as a very data-driven company also has the maturity to help clearly quantify designer's contribution and impact. This is very helpful at the time of portfolio / case study creation as well. Finally, the scale at which Gojek operates (100s of millions of users) means that even the smallest project in relative terms, absolutely has an enormous impact in absolute terms. The culture in terms of day to day interactions is also very good. There are not many opportunities in India where you get to work with people all around the world, and get exposed to other cultures and ways of working. Further Gojek name on the resume carries a lot of brand value with future employers.
summary: Great place to work, but issues with bad HR policies, frequent layoffs, and slow pace of execution

advice: Despite the cons, it's a decent org to work for, albeit for a short time, with streamlined processes and significantly better culture compared to Indian orgs of the same stature. My advice to management would be to relook at the growth and mentorship setup within the org (especially the product org). For the rest, keep doing what you're doing.
cons:
- It's hard to grow within the organisation. Product org is mired in politics, especially under the new HR and product regimes since late 2019. Promotions are often arbitrarily denied and managers tend to act helpless in the matter citing the whims of 'powers that be'. There is very little transparency here, unlike other aspects of the org, and definitely makes up for a toxic pattern when it come to professional growth. My advice would be to not stick around more than a year and a half. Leave soon after you hear a flimsy excuse or any grand promises about the 'next performance cycle'
- Significant disparity in pay within the same org level. The org overtly advocates salary parity but salary bands are not public information. You may find yourself grossly underpaid (sometimes well below your org-mandated salary band) compared to other colleagues at the same level if you don't keep your ear to the ground. I was underpaid as per my band for almost a year before I found out. Colleagues here are generally very reluctant to talk about levels and salaries amongst themselves as well.

advice:
When I joined the team was brilliant, the culture was dynamic and the goal was to build an app that people would love, and the org was super transparent.

Starting 2019-2020, as the org has grown so much, middle management has been hired at a rapid pace without apparently checking for a culture fit - the whole system turned into an opaque, bureaucratic one where the only thing that matters are processes, vying for the spotlight and he said/she said, rather than pushing an amazing product to the user.

And because of all this, employee experience is seriously impacted too. All the benefits that Gojek so proudly boasts of? Well none of them are really valid anymore. A work life balance did exist at a certain point, but now there's an expectation for you to work from 4am to 10pm.

I'd say that Gojek Tech is but a shadow of its former amazing self.
cons: Middle management, culture, bureaucracy, opaqueness, no defined growth path, salary
pros: Engineering team, work life balance

advice:
- Focus on outcomes, and not just delivery.

- Find the right balance between top-down and bottom-up work culture

cons:
I was at GoJek for around a year - Built out and launched key products, interacted directly with CEO/ CXO/ SVP/ leadership. Few observations :

-  Lack of data-driven decision making - There's no culture of evidence (qualitative/ quantitative) based product strategy. Just ideas made up in the air based on "visionary thinking of the CEO" or some hearsay/ article read by some SVP.  They'd change their decisions over the fly over a couple of Whatsapp conversations without full context of the decision.

- Project Management (and not Product management) - When I joined, I was pleasantly surprised that GoJek got so big with the current product culture - but after a few months, I realised that the success of GoJek was its ability replicate US/ India/ China models in a greenfield market like Indonesia really quickly. Not focusing on innovation, but focusing on rapid replication + delivery. Not focusing on iterative experimentation, but just speed of shipping features. Works/ worked for Indonesia, but detrimental to the growth of a Product manager's leadership/ analytical thinking.

- *Very* hierarchal - The decisions are pushed downwards from the SVP/ GM/ CXO, and the Senior Product managers act like Project managers executing a mandate given from the top. It was sad to see limited bottom-up input in Product strategy (akin to Chinese product work culture).

- Lack of management & top-tech exposure at the leadership level - Although there's a lot of fan-fare around how the CEO is a game-changer for Indonesia (and maybe its true from an Indonesian context), I believe there's a lack of management/ leadership at the CXO/ SVP level. Few in the senior leadership have exposure working at Top-tech companies (FAANG/ Tier 2 Tech) previously, leading to a lack of understanding around how to build product teams, and building the right product culture.

- Indo favouritism at the leadership level - There's a sense of favouritism if you're an Indonesian at the leadership level. That's an accepted fact across the company (and sometimes even acknowledged by the leadership in the name of patriotism) - but is very unhealthy and non-inclusive in the long run.

Lots of areas of improvement for Gojek.

Scale of product in a greenfield market != Successful work culture.
Please lay a huge emphasis on improving the same.
